title: Fascinating images reveal insight into how people with colour blindness see make up
text:
When selecting make-up, it can be difficult to choose the perfect colour or shade - a choice that could be made even harder if you're colour blind.

To coincide with World Sight Day this Thursday, YesStyle, an Asian fashion blog, have released a fascinating selection of images to show what it’s like to live with colour-blindness.

Colour vision deficiency is surprisingly common, and is reported to affect one in 12 men and one in 200 women around the world, with a total of 2.7 million sufferers in the UK alone.

While those with full vision may see an array of different eye shadows, lipsticks and nail colours in the photos, those with a colour blindness will likely see a duller landscape - heavily dominated by fewer vibrant colours.

‹ Slide me › Fascinating images have shown just what the beauty world looks like if you suffer from colour blindness (pictured left, a selection of make-up if if you have full vision, and right, how it looks if you have Deuteranopia - a form of colour blindness which means sufferers are unable to distinguish green from red, as well as some grays, purples and a greenish blue)

‹ Slide me › Others who suffer from varying colour blindness conditions may see a different tint to their makeup (pictured left, a sufferer of Tritanopia and right, a person with Protanopia)

While those suffering from Deuteranopia may be see a grey and dull landscape lacking in bold reds, others who have Tritanopia may find they're unable to see yellow and blue colours.

Different forms of colour blindness may impact the way that sufferers perceive or wear their make-up.

For those who suffer from a colour vision deficiency like Deuteranopia, Tritanopia or Protanopia, the sufferer may struggle to differentiate make-up colours due to the heavy colour tint which dominates their vision.

So while those with full vision may see a make-up palette of blues, yellows, reds and greens, it's likely those who have a colour vision deficiency would struggle to see the full variety of colours.

‹ Slide me › Meanwhile it may be more difficult to detect hair colour for those affected by colour blindness (pictured left, a person with full-vision, and right, a person suffering from Deuteranopia)

Deuteranopia is one of the most common colour vision deficiencies, along Protanopia.

Rather than seeing a bold landscape of bright and diverse eye shadow palettes and lipstick colours, those who suffer from Deuteranopia are more likely to see a much duller, greyer sight.

Deutranopia sufferers see an absence of green and red colours, giving their vision a kind of heavy blue and yellow tint.

This means eyeshadows take on a heavy yellow or blue colour, while lipsticks will appear completely dulled.

WHAT IS COLOUR BLINDNESS? Approximately one in 20 people suffer from colour blindness, a condition that makes the world a duller place to look at. According to the NHS, it affects 1 in 200 women in the world and 1 in 12 men. Protanopia Protanopia involves defective or absent long-wavelength cones in the retina; these photoreceptor cones are responsible for the perception of red light. Protans find it difficult to distinguish between red and green colours, and also between blue and green. Deuteranopia Deuteranopia is a condition where the green photoreceptor cone is missing from the retina. As a result, it is much harder for deutans to distinguish green from red, as well as some grays, purples and a greenish blue. Along with protanopia this is one of the most common forms of colour blindness. Tritanopia Tritanopia is a complete lack of the short-wavelength cones in the retina that receive blue light. People with this very rare form of colour blindness confuse light blues with greys, dark purples with black, mid-greens with blues and oranges with reds.

Their colour blindness is caused by an absence of medium wavelength retinal cones – these are primarily green sensitive, although the deficiency greatly affects how people perceive red as well.

Meanwhile people who have Tritanopia may find they suffer from a blindness of blue and yellow colours. This can mean their vision is dominated by red or green tones.

‹ Slide me › The world of manicures and nail art may also be different for those suffering from a form of colour blindness (pictured left, a person with full vision and right, a person with Tritanopia - a form of colour blindness that affects blue and yellow colours)

It’s caused by an absence of short wavelength retinal cones – these are primarily blue sensitive, although the deficiency greatly affects how people see yellow as well.

While it may mean they're able to select a bold red or pink as a lipstick, it could also give eyeshadows and skin makeup a heavy reddish tint.

Those with protanopia suffer from a blindness to red and green colours - and it appears very similar to deuteranopia.

‹ Slide me › Meanwhile those who suffer from Protanopia will see similar colours to those with Deuteranopia - although the colours will likely be duller and darker (pictured left, a person with full vision and right, a person with Deuteranopia)

It’s caused by an absence of long wavelength retinal cones – these are primarily red sensitive, although the deficiency greatly affects how people see green as well.

Those suffering from Protanopia find it difficult to distinguish between red and green colours, and also between blue and green.

In terms of what people with protanopia see, the results are very similar to deuteranopia but with a slight dimmer and duller effect.
description: To coincide with World Sight Day on Thursday, YesStyle, an Asian fashion blog, have released fascinating images to reveal how those suffering from colour blindness view makeup and beauty.
